snippet: Orthodox and Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn are increasingly turning to the Japanese dish (but without shellfish) because it provides dietary flexibility.
abstract: Sushi distributors say dish has become runaway hit in New York City’s Hasidic and Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods, with almost 100 new kosher sushi bars cropping up within last 5 to 10 years; kosher restaurateurs say trend is fueled by food's status as neither meat nor dairy product meaning it can be eaten at any time without breaking Jewish dietary laws.
lead_paragraph: Orthodox and Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn are increasingly turning to the Japanese dish (but without shellfish) because it provides dietary flexibility.

headline.main: Enough With the Gefilte Fish. I’ll Have Sushi.
headline.print_headline: Enough With the Gefilte Fish. I’ll Have Sushi.
